title: Grizzly Bear!
text: A massive grizzly charges toward the riverbank! Lewis once described one chasing him into the river. What do you do?

choices.result: The bear stops, studies your group, and lumbers away. Bold move — Lewis would approve!
The bear loses interest and wanders off. Smart — the Corps often used the river as an escape route!
Running triggers the bear's chase instinct! It follows for 50 yards before giving up. Never run from a grizzly!

title: River Rapids Ahead!
text: The Missouri's current is fierce — your boats are tossed sideways! Everyone grabs their poles. How do you navigate?

choices.text: ⚓ Rope the boat to shore and portage
choices.result: Safe but slow. You lose half a day hauling gear around the rapids. The Corps portaged around falls for nearly a month!
Your crew powers through! Some supplies get soaked but nothing is lost. The men cheer as you clear the rapids!
The river doesn't calm down. After wasting a full day, you portage anyway. Lewis noted the river 'never rests.'

title: Thunderstorm on the Plains!
text: A violent thunderstorm rolls in fast. Lightning cracks across the open prairie with no shelter in sight!

choices.text: ⛺ Set up camp in a low spot
choices.result: Good thinking! Clark once barely escaped a flash flood in a ravine, but your low ground stays dry. You wait out the storm safely.
Lightning strikes a tree nearby! Never shelter under tall trees in a storm. The Corps learned this the hard way.
Soaked to the bone but still moving. The Corps often had no choice but to march through rain for days.

title: Mosquito Swarm!
text: Clouds of mosquitoes descend on your camp! Clark wrote he 'could not keep them off my gun long enough to take aim.' Fight back!
success_text: You swatted enough mosquitoes to get some relief! The Corps burned green wood to create smoke — it was the only thing that helped.
fail_text: The mosquitoes win this round! Your arms are covered in welts. The Corps endured this torment every single night on the plains.

title: Elk Herd Spotted!
text: A large herd of elk grazes nearby. The hunters need to bring down meat — the Corps ate up to 9 pounds per person per day!

choices.result: Two elk brought down cleanly! That's over 800 pounds of meat. Drouillard would be proud — he was the expedition's best hunter.
The herd scatters before you get close. No meat today. Patience and skill were essential for frontier hunting.
You catch one small elk. Not a feast, but it will keep the party fed for a couple of days.

title: Prickly Pear Cactus Field!
text: The trail is carpeted with prickly pear cactus. Sharp spines pierce through your moccasins with every step!
success_text: You dodged most of the cactus! Lewis called prickly pear 'one of the beauties as well as the greatest pests of the plains.'
fail_text: Ouch! Your moccasins are shredded and your feet are bleeding. The men had to stop constantly to pull out spines during the Great Falls portage.

title: A Friendly Camp
text: You encounter a group of Native Americans who offer to trade. What do you bring to the meeting?

choices.result: They appreciate the colorful beads! Lewis and Clark carried 33 pounds of beads specifically for trade and diplomacy.
The chief accepts the medal with ceremony. Peace medals were the most important diplomatic gifts Lewis carried.

choices.text: 🔫 Show your weapons to impress them
choices.result: The display creates tension, not friendship. Clark learned that gifts and respect worked better than shows of force.

title: Fork in the River!
text: The river splits into two branches. Which fork is the true Missouri? Choose wrong and you could lose weeks!

choices.result: Correct! This happened at the Marias River. The men all voted for the north fork, but Lewis and Clark chose the south — and they were right!
That's the Marias River — a dead end! The Corps would have lost weeks. Lewis trusted his scientific observations over the popular vote.
Smart! Lewis did exactly this — he scouted the south fork for days before committing. Scientific caution saved the expedition.

title: Wolves at Night!
text: As darkness falls, wolves howl all around your camp. Clark noted 'a great number of wolves about us all night.' Guard the camp!
success_text: You kept the wolves at bay! The sentries earned their rest. The Corps always posted guards through the night.
fail_text: The wolves got into the provisions! You lost some dried meat. The Corps learned to hang food high and keep watch.

title: Bitter Cold!
text: Temperatures plummet to -20°F! At Fort Mandan it dropped to -45°F. How does your party survive the night?

choices.text: 🔥 Build a big fire and huddle close
choices.result: The fire keeps everyone warm enough to survive. At Fort Mandan, the men kept fires burning constantly for five months.
Body heat plus leather — it works! The men often slept two to a bed during the coldest nights.
Marching in -20°F wastes energy fast. Several men get frostbite. Lewis noted that exposed skin 'froze in minutes.'
